Intermediate Algebra_Level 1_2.json.problem:
Find the real roots of
\[x^4 - 2x^3 - x + 2 = 0.\]
Intermediate Algebra_Level 1_2.json.correct_solution:
We can factor the polynomial as
\begin{align*}
x^4 - 2x^3 - x + 2 &= (x - 2) x^3 - (x - 2) \\
&= (x - 2)(x^3 - 1) \\
&= (x - 2)(x - 1)(x^2 + x + 1).
\end{align*}The quadratic factor $x^2 + x + 1$ has no real roots, so the real roots are $\boxed{1,2}.$

generated_solutions.gemini-1.5-flash:
We can try to factor by grouping.  We can group the terms as follows:
\[(x^4 - 2x^3) + (-x + 2) = 0.\]Factoring out $x^3$ from the first group and $-1$ from the second group, we get
\[x^3 (x - 2) - 1(x - 2) = 0.\]Now, we can factor out $(x - 2)$ to get
\[(x - 2)(x^3 - 1) = 0.\]The first factor gives us the solution $x = 2$.  The second factor factors as a difference of cubes:
\[(x - 1)(x^2 + x + 1) = 0.\]The quadratic factor has no real roots, so the only real root of the equation is $x = \boxed{2}$.
